supporting_quotes: Primakov was educated at the Moscow Institute of Oriental Studies, graduating in 1953
carried out postgraduate work at Moscow State University

From 1956 to 1970, he worked as a journalist for Soviet radio and a Middle Eastern correspondent for Pravda newspaper. During this time, he was sent frequently on intelligence missions to the Middle East and the United States as a KGB co-optee under codename MAKSIM.

organizations: Institute of World Economy and International Relations
supporting_quotes: As a Senior Researcher at the Institute of World Economy and International Relations, Primakov entered into scientific society in 1962.

organizations: Institute of World Economy and International Relations
Academy of Sciences of the Soviet Union
supporting_quotes: From 30 December 1970 to 1977, he served as deputy director of the Institute of World Economy and International Relations, part of the Academy of Sciences of the Soviet Union.

organizations: Institute of Oriental Studies of the USSR Academy of Sciences
supporting_quotes: From 1977 to 1985 he was Director of the Institute of Oriental Studies of the USSR Academy of Sciences.
During this time he was also First Deputy Chairman of the Soviet Peace Committee.

organizations: Institute of World Economy and International Relations
supporting_quotes: In 1985 he returned to the Institute of World Economy and International Relations, serving as Director until 1989.

organizations: Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union
roles: Chairman of the Soviet of the Union
supporting_quotes: Primakov became involved in national politics in 1989, as the Chairman of the Soviet of the Union, one of two chambers of the Soviet parliament.

organizations: 27th Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union
supporting_quotes: 1989–1990: Candidate member, 27th Politburo

organizations: Presidential Council of the Soviet Union
supporting_quotes: From 1990 until 1991 he was a member of Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's Presidential Council of the Soviet Union.
He served as Gorbachev's special envoy to Iraq in the run-up to the Persian Gulf War

roles: First Deputy Chairman of the KGB
Director of the KGB First Chief Directorate
supporting_quotes: After the failed August 1991 putsch, Primakov was appointed First Deputy Chairman of the KGB and Director of the KGB First Chief Directorate responsible for foreign intelligence.
Director of the USSR Central Intelligence Service In office 6 November 1991 – 26 December 1991

After the formation of the Russian Federation, Primakov shepherded the transition of the KGB First Chief Directorate to the control of the Russian Federation government, under the new name Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR).
He served as SVR director from 1991 until 1996.

organizations: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia
supporting_quotes: Primakov served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from January 1996 until September 1998.
was a Russian politician and diplomat who served as Prime Minister of Russia from 1998 to 1999
Before Yeltsin's resignation, Primakov supported the Fatherland – All Russia electoral faction, which at that time was the major opponent of the pro-Putin Unity, and launched his presidential bid.
Primakov officially abandoned the presidential race in his TV address on 4 February 2000
Soon he became an adviser to Putin and a political ally.

organizations: Russian Chamber of Commerce and Industry
supporting_quotes: On 14 December 2001, Primakov became President of the Russian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, a position he held until 2011.

roles: special representative of President Putin to Iraq
supporting_quotes: In February and March 2003, he visited Iraq and held talks with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, as a special representative of President Putin.
On 26 May 2008, Primakov was elected as a member of the Presidium of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
Primakov was an academician (Arabist) and a member of the Presidium of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
Recipient of the Nasser Prize (1974)
Recipient of the USSR State Prize (1980)
Recipient of the Avicenna Prize (1983)
Recipient of the George F. Kennan Prize (1990)
Recipient of the Hugo Grotius Prize for the huge contribution to the development of international law and for the creation of a multipolar world doctrine (2000).
In 2009, the University of Niš, Serbia awarded Primakov an honorary doctorate.
Demidov Prize (2012)

organizations: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
supporting_quotes: In November 2004, Primakov testified in defense of the former Yugoslav President Slobodan Milošević, on trial for war crimes.
